author: By Francesca Paris
title: Did You Recently Choose Between Renting and Buying? We Want to Hear About It.
description: The New York Times is telling the stories of people who made this difficult choice. Maybe we can tell yours.
content: The New York Times recently republished its Rent vs. Buy calculator, designed to help our readers make one of life’s biggest financial decisions. But the choice to rent or buy a home is based on much more than just numbers — it’s also about neighborhoods, schools, family, and what the future might hold. We want to tell those stories, too. Have you gone through the buy-versus-rent debate in the past year or two? Did you think you were going to rent a home, but end up buying? Did you come close to making an offer on a home, then renew your lease instead? We want to hear from you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Best Films of 2024, So Far
description: Our critics pick nine films that they think are worth your time on this long holiday weekend.
content: Looking for a good movie to pass the time this Memorial Day weekend? The New York Times’s chief film critic, Manohla Dargis, and movie critic, Alissa Wilkinson, have you covered. Here are their top picks for the year so far. All are in theaters or available on demand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Trump’s Taste for Tyranny Finds a Target
description: Once you start talk about immigrants “poisoning the blood of our country,” what comes next?
content: Among the worst episodes in American history are those moments when the federal government deploys the full weight of its power against the most vulnerable people in the country: the Trail of Tears and the Fugitive Slave Act in the 19th century and Japanese internment in the middle of the 20th, to name three.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Zach Montague
title: Obama Is a Surprise Guest Among Allies at Biden’s State Dinner for Kenya
description: The state dinner was held in honor of the African nation, but it was clear that the night was about keeping Democratic allies close as President Biden heads into the heat of the 2024 campaign season.
content: Yes, Barack Obama was there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The Top U.N. Court Told Israel to Halt Its Rafah Offensive
description: Also, countries failed to agree on how to prepare for the next pandemic. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
content: The International Court of Justice ruled today that Israel must immediately halt its military offensive in the southern Gazan city of Rafah.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith and María Garrido
title: The Capital of Women’s Soccer
description: The success of Barcelona’s team has made Catalonia a laboratory for finding out what happens when the women’s game has prominence similar to the men’s.
content: A little more than an hour before the game begins, the gates outside the Johan Cruyff Stadium swing open and a thousand or so fans rush inside. Some scurry to the turnstiles. Others wait patiently at the merchandise stalls, anxious to buy a jersey, a scarf, a commemorative trinket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Judge Denies Alec Baldwin’s Bid to Dismiss Manslaughter Indictment
description: The ruling increases the likelihood that Mr. Baldwin will stand trial this summer in the fatal shooting of a cinematographer on the set of the film “Rust.”
content: A judge in New Mexico denied Alec Baldwin’s bid to dismiss the involuntary manslaughter charge he faces in the fatal shooting of a cinematographer on the set of the movie “Rust,” ruling on Friday that the case had been properly presented to a grand jury.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: At the Kenya State Dinner, Jill Biden Is True Blue
description: In Sergio Hudson, the first lady is stepping up her fashion diplomacy game.
content: There are few moments of political theater as grand as a state dinner, essentially a pantomime of diplomacy and national pride from the set to the staging to the scripts — and the costumes. In that drama, the first lady is cast as both hostess and symbol, her dress a part of the decorative storytelling of the night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Gratz
title: Can Reading About Trauma Help Kids Cope?
description: Two new picture books dive into refugee childhoods.
content: Do children’s books about frightening events make the very young more afraid, or do they comfort them?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Grace Lee
title: The ‘Nontraditional’ Bridal Brand Capturing Hearts Online
description: Madison Chamberlain is carving a niche with her vibrant, over-the-top bridal designs.
content: “Make me look like a disco ball.” For most designers this isn’t a common request, but for Madison Chamberlain, so-called disco brides, and anyone looking to splash extra color, sparkle or glam into their wedding day, are a mainstay of her business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anastasia Tsioulcas
title: Review: A Delightful ‘Orfeo’ Returns to the Met Opera
description: The countertenor Anthony Roth Costanzo stars in a revival of Mark Morris’s witty, sensitively choreographed production.
content: Gluck’s opera “Orfeo ed Euridice” is a funny thing: a timeless Greek myth of separation and loss, twisted into a Viennese cream puff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Landslide Buries Village in Papua New Guinea, Killing at Least 3
description: Many more were missing in the Pacific nation as recovery and rescue efforts were delayed by a blocked highway and fallen boulders.
content: A massive landslide devastated a remote village in Papua New Guinea early Friday, killing at least three people and leaving many more missing, as at least 100 homes were damaged and water, power and a major highway were cut off, United Nations officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: U.S. Approves Investment Product Tied to Popular Cryptocurrency Ether
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission gave its blessing to a fund that tracks the price of the most valuable cryptocurrency after Bitcoin.
content: Federal regulators on Thursday approved an investment product tied to the cryptocurrency Ether, the most valuable digital asset after Bitcoin, in a major boost for the crypto industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: ‘Artificial Intelligence’? No, Collective Intelligence.
description: The artist and musician Holly Herndon explores the promise — and complications — of collaborating with A.I.
content: A.I.-generated art has flooded the internet, and a lot of it is derivative, even boring or offensive. But what could it look like for artists to collaborate with A.I. systems in making art that is actually generative, challenging, transcendent?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: NASA Astronauts to Wait Another Week for Boeing Starliner Launch
description: Officials from NASA and Boeing say they have worked out a solution to a helium leak that has kept the Starliner astronaut capsule grounded.
content: Boeing’s Starliner spacecraft, which was scheduled to take two NASA astronauts to the International Space Station on May 6, will remain on the ground for at least another week as engineers chase down a small helium leak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: What Set the A.T.F. and an Airport Leader on the Path to a Deadly Encounter?
description: Bryan Malinowski was the executive director of the airport in Little Rock, Ark., and sold firearms at gun shows. Federal agents believed he was breaking the law.
content: The loud noises outside their bedroom door woke them before dawn. Bryan Malinowski bolted up and looked at his wife, Maer. “Stay back,” she remembers him saying after he reached into a drawer for his gun and loaded it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: ‘Atlas’ Review: A.I. Shrugged
description: Jennifer Lopez stars in a sci-fi action thriller that wonders whether artificial intelligence is really all that bad.
content: In 1927, a humanoid robot showed up and wreaked havoc in Fritz Lang’s expressionist science fiction film “Metropolis,” a memorable early example of cinema’s artificial intelligence antagonists. Since then, many a sci-fi movie, from “2001: A Space Odyssey” to the “Terminator” offerings to “The Matrix,” has proposed that some kind of A.I. will try to take us out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Raw Milk’s Risks Don’t Stop Right-Wing Commentators From Defiantly Pushing It
description: On sites like Infowars, Gab and Rumble, federal concerns about raw milk are seen as overreach, but there are serious health risks and no scientifically proven benefits.
content: Health officials are warning Americans not to drink raw milk as bird flu spreads through American cows. But some media figures and influencers are misleadingly suggesting that the product is safe or even healthier than traditional milk. And sales are growing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: A Bouquet of Songs for May Flowers
description: Tom Petty, Patrice Rushen, Billie Eilish and more.
content: Last month, I sent you a playlist of rainy songs, in honor of April showers. I also promised a sequel. I bet you have spent weeks racking your brain thinking what that playlist’s theme could possibly be. Well, wonder no more. It’s time for a selection of songs about (say it with me) …. um, no, not bell towers. And also not cauliflower, but that’s a fun guess.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Nikki Haley’s Path Back to Donald Trump
description: Readers offer their analysis of why she said she would vote for him. Also: Blaming the wife; maligning Justice Juan Merchan; a caregiver’s story.
content: To the Editor:

content: “This is much more than the old-time paper charting.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Books Staff
title: The Best Books of the Year (So Far)
description: The nonfiction and novels we can’t stop thinking about.
content: We’re almost halfway through 2024 and we at The Book Review have already written about hundreds of books. Some of those titles are good. Some are very good. And then there are the following.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Interest on Federal Student Loans Is Rising to 6.53%
description: The rate for undergraduate loans is up from 5.5 percent this past school year and higher than it has been in more than a decade.
content: This has already been a challenging year for college applicants, starting with the problems with a crucial federal form that delayed financial aid offers. Now, students and families have more to worry about: The cost of borrowing for college for the next school year is rising to the highest rate in more than a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Houman Barekat
title: ‘Romeo and Juliet’ Review: Plenty of Style, but Little Love
description: The London production, starring Tom Holland, sold out in hours. But its understated rendering of the central romance may leave some theatergoers wanting more.
content: As the male lead entered the stage in a new production of “Romeo and Juliet” in London, a single, very loud whoop erupted from the orchestra level. Nobody else joined in — this is Britain, after all — but the breach of decorum was telling. This particular Romeo is the big-screen superstar Tom Holland, of “Spider-Man” fame, and his pulling power helped tickets for this show’s run sell out within hours — even though the actor playing Juliet wasn’t cast until many weeks later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alison Gregor
title: $750,000 Homes in Barbados
description: A colonial-style townhouse, a four-bedroom house with a turret and koi pond, and a one-bedroom condominium in a beachfront midrise.
content: This two-bedroom, two-bath townhouse with Atlantic Ocean views is in the Forest Hills enclave and situated inside the gated Royal Westmoreland golf and beach resort, on the western side of Barbados. Covering about 750 verdant acres overlooking the Caribbean island’s “Platinum Coast,” the Royal Westmoreland resort includes as championship 18-hole golf course, a beach club at nearby Mullins Beach, several restaurants, facilities for racket sports, and a pool, spa and gym, among other amenities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: At a Trump Rally in the Bronx, Chants of ‘Build the Wall’
description: Speaking to a more diverse crowd than his events usually draw, Donald Trump made a series of pledges to New Yorkers and railed against President Biden and the migrant crisis.
content: Miles from the rather somber Manhattan courtroom where he has spent much of the past five weeks as a criminal defendant, former President Donald J. Trump on Thursday stood at a park in the Bronx, surveyed the crowd and acknowledged he had been concerned over how he might be greeted at his first rally in New York State in eight years, and his first ever in the borough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Vivienne Walt
title: Are University Athletes About to Earn a Big Payday?
description: A $2.8 billion class-action settlement proposal could finally erase the notion that college stars are amateurs — though the plan has drawn skeptics.
content: The other shoe has dropped for the N.C.A.A.: That college sports association just agreed to a $2.8 billion class-action settlement that, if approved by a judge in California, would pay student athletes after a century of deeming them amateurs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Younger Adults Are Missing Early Warning Signs of Colon Cancer
description: A new analysis of dozens of studies has identified the most common warning symptoms in adults under 50, whose rates of colon and rectal cancer are on the rise.
content: Colorectal cancer rates are rapidly rising among adults in their 20s, 30s and 40s, and the most common warning sign for the disease is passing blood in the stool, according to a new scientific review.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: How ‘Furiosa’ Fits Into the ‘Mad Max’ Timeline
description: “Furiosa” is a prequel that intersects with the earlier movies in surprising ways. Here’s a chronology, plus our ideal order for watching the whole series.
content: “Furiosa: A Mad Max Saga” is roaring into theaters, widely advertised as a prequel to the director George Miller’s 2015 hit, “Mad Max: Fury Road.” But that was the fourth film in a series that, until now, was chronological, so where does “Furiosa” fit in? How else do these movies intersect, with the numerous cast changes and recalibrations in the 45 years since the inaugural entry? Whether you’re approaching the franchise as a novice or looking for a quick refresher, here’s how it all fits together:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: G.O.P. and Secret Service Clash Again Over Convention Protest Zone
description: Lawyers for the Republican National Convention asked again for the Secret Service to relocate a protest zone for the party’s convention in July. The agency quickly pushed back.
content: The Republican National Committee, alarmed by what it sees as a significantly worsening security threat, asked on Thursday that the director of the Secret Service personally intervene and grant a request to move a designated protest zone farther away from convention participants in Milwaukee this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: Why Bad Commencement Speeches Are a Good Thing
description: At a time of extreme polarization on campus, the banality of the graduation ceremony is a tradition worth celebrating.
content: Over the past few weekends, graduating seniors at American colleges and universities have been reminded of the necessity of laughter, the importance of failure and the need for empathy in a troubled and divided world.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Holly Herndon
description: The May 24, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Holly Herndon. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Forsythe
title: Chinese Billionaire Accused of Fraud Didn’t Need the Money, Lawyers Say
description: Prosecutors put Guo Wengui on trial in New York for defrauding investors of $1 billion. His lawyers told jurors he was building an anti-Communist movement.
content: Lawyers for Guo Wengui, an exiled Chinese billionaire charged with defrauding investors of more than $1 billion, portrayed him on Friday as the dedicated leader of an anti-Communist movement who did not need the money he is accused of stealing.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 24, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, May 24, 2024.
content: An article on Wednesday about a video posted by Former President Donald J. Trump on Truth Social incorrectly described templates available from the web design company Envato, which was used in its creation. Parts of Envato’s templates are customizable and allow users to alter the background text, not only the headlines and photos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Carl Zimmer, Alex Stern, Stella Tan, Sydney Harper, Nina Feldman, MJ Davis Lin, Elisheba Ittoop, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Sophia Lanman, Pat McCusker and Alyssa Moxley
title: Whales Have an Alphabet
description: Until the 1960s, it was uncertain whether whales made any sounds at all.
content: Ever since the discovery of whale songs almost 60 years ago, scientists have been trying to decipher the lyrics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on What Constitutes ‘Visiting’ a State
description: Does it count if you never leave the car?
content: Caroline writes: My husband and sons and I stick a pin in a map whenever we visit a new state. But we disagree about what counts. They say if we cross the border in a car, even if we don’t get out, we’ve visited. I say no. Where does one draw the line?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Would You Want a Robot to Speak at Your Graduation?
description: An A.I. robot gave a commencement address at a university in Buffalo. What do you think? Who would you want to speak at your graduation?
content: It’s graduation season — a time for caps and gowns, tears, hugs and inspirational speeches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Friday Briefing
description: We’re covering a stumbling U.S. aid effort in Gaza and the latest Chinese military drills around Taiwan.
content: The U.S. predicted that a floating pier off Gaza built by its military would allow for a steady stream of humanitarian aid. But little relief has reached Palestinians in the strip, officials said this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How Algebra Became a Flashpoint in Schools
description: A tug of war in San Francisco over whether to teach algebra in eighth or ninth grade gets at wider national questions about serving all students fairly.
content: Controversy over school curriculum is nothing new. But one subject that has led to lawsuits, ballot measures and fighting among parents, teachers and district officials may come as a surprise: It’s algebra.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: DanceAfrica Brings Cameroon to Brooklyn
description: DanceAfrica Festival 2024, the nation’s largest festival of African dance, is what some consider Brooklyn’s unofficial start to summer.
content: Good morning. Today, and on Fridays through the summer, we’ll focus on things to do in New York over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Bergin
title: Australia’s ‘National Crisis’ of Domestic Abuse
description: The government has committed hundreds of millions of dollars for people fleeing domestic violence, but among those who work with victims and survivors, optimism is hard to find.
content: Late last month, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese declared that violence against women had become a “national crisis.” His comments came after thousands rallied in Australia’s big cities to demand action from the government in the face of alarming statistics, with activists identifying at least 29 women who have been killed in Australia so far this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: The Anti-Trump Republicans Worried About the Biden Campaign
description: Some G.O.P. Trump opponents want to hear more from the Biden campaign. It says it’s on it.
content: Earlier this week, a couple of former Republican members of Congress sent an email to dozens of fellow G.O.P. retirees with a clear and urgent subject line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: A State Fund That Helps Children Hurt at Birth Is Quietly Suspended
description: New York officials said the fund would accept new beneficiaries into the new year, but a projected shortfall of at least $3.2 billion raises questions about its future.
content: For more than a decade, a little-known New York State fund has paid the medical expenses of children who have suffered neurological injuries as a result of medical malpractice during childbirth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: The Shaky Foundation of Trump’s Lead: Disengaged Voters
description: The Biden team faces questions of its own: Why have these voters backed away from him, and can his campaign find a way to reach them?
content: The polls have shown Donald J. Trump with an edge for eight straight months, but there’s one big flashing warning sign suggesting that his advantage might not be quite as stable as it looks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner and Luis Antonio Rojas
title: A Mexican Taco Stand Goes From Local Favorite to Michelin Darling
description: Taquería El Califa de León, in Mexico City, became the first Mexican taco stand to win a Michelin star. Since then, it has been deluged with customers and fame.
content: Over a week ago, Taquería El Califa de León was simply one of Mexico City’s nearly 11,000 registered taco shops, though there are undoubtedly many more that aren’t. Sure, it had been around nearly 60 years and was popular, especially among politicians who worked nearby. But it was mostly a locally known taco stand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: U.C.L.A. Police Make First Arrest in Attack on Protest Encampment
description: Edan On, an 18-year-old, was charged with assault. The police said he beat pro-Palestinian protesters with a wooden pole.
content: More than three weeks after counterprotesters attacked a pro-Palestinian encampment at the University of California, Los Angeles, the university police have made the first arrest related to the attack: an 18-year-old who officers said had beaten pro-Palestinian protesters with a wooden pole.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: U.A.W. Seeks a New Election at Mercedes-Benz Plants in Alabama
description: The union, which lost an organizing vote at two factories last week, argued to federal officials that the automaker had violated labor laws.
content: A week after losing a hard-fought election at two Mercedes-Benz factories in Alabama, the United Automobile Workers asked federal officials on Friday to order a new vote, saying the German carmaker violated labor laws to suppress support for the union.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger and Ryan Mac
title: Elon Musk Ramps Up Anti-Biden Posts on X
description: The billionaire owner of X has increasingly been using his social media platform to criticize President Biden for his health and immigration policies, according to a New York Times analysis.
content: Last month, Elon Musk posted on X that President Biden “obviously barely knows what’s going on.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: New York Man Who Grabbed Officer’s Pepper Spray on Jan. 6 Pleads Guilty
description: Troy Weeks was at “the site of some of the most violent attacks against law enforcement” during the U.S. Capitol riot, prosecutors said.
content: An upstate New York man who grabbed a police officer’s can of pepper spray as he and other supporters of former President Donald J. Trump rioted at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, has pleaded guilty to federal felony and misdemeanor charges, prosecutors said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Justice Sotomayor Describes Frustration With Being a Liberal on the Supreme Court
description: In a conversation at Harvard, the justice spoke of her despair at some of the court’s decisions, but she urged optimism and a focus on future generations.
content: Some days, after Justice Sonia Sotomayor listens to the Supreme Court announce its decisions, she goes into her chambers, shuts the door and weeps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Ponsor
title: A Federal Judge Wonders: How Could Alito Have Been So Foolish?
description: Displaying an upside-down American flag shouldn’t have happened.
content: The controversy about the decision to fly an upside-down American flag outside the home of Justice Samuel Alito recalls St. Paul’s admonition that while some things may be lawful, “not all things are helpful.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Decades in the Making, a New Era Dawns for the N.C.A.A.: Paying Athletes Directly
description: If approved by a judge, the $2.8 billion settlement of an antitrust lawsuit would allow for the first revenue-sharing plan for college athletes. The question now: How will it work?
content: Since its founding, the N.C.A.A. has operated with a business model that defined the college athlete as an amateur. Over the years, as college sports evolved into a mega-enterprise, lawsuits and labor actions chipped away at that model, which came to be increasingly seen as exploitative in big-money sports like football and men’s basketball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman and Johnatan Reiss
title: Israeli Forces Recover Bodies of 3 More Hostages in Northern Gaza
description: The bodies were found in Jabaliya, where the Israeli military has been trying to root out a renewed Hamas insurgency.
content: Israeli forces retrieved the bodies of three Oct. 7 Hamas attack victims in an overnight operation in northern Gaza, the Israeli military said on Friday, further heightening fears for the fate of the remaining hostages held in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Egypt’s President Agrees to Reopen Crossing for Gaza Aid After Biden Call
description: Fuel and humanitarian aid will be able to enter Gaza through Kerem Shalom, an Israeli-operated crossing, the White House said.
content: Egypt has agreed to allow fuel and humanitarian aid to move from its territory into Gaza via Israel, the White House and the Egyptian presidency announced on Friday, reopening a vital channel for relief into the devastated Palestinian enclave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Women Have Gotten ‘Too Mouthy,’ Says This Republican Senate Candidate
description: Alex Jones, Steve Bannon and the left-to-right pipeline.
content: Royce White, a Black former pro basketball player who led protests in Minneapolis after the murder of George Floyd, made his first appearance on “The Alex Jones Show” about two years ago. As he spoke, it became clear that the deep suspicion of government authority that inspired him to march in the summer of 2020 had carried him into Jones’s paranoid orbit. “We all know when the time comes and authoritarianism is at its peak, the police and the troops who just take marching orders are going to be the ones forcibly vaccinating you and your kids,” he said. Jones, a purveyor of conspiracy theories about everything from 9/11 to the murder of children at Sandy Hook Elementary School, was thrilled by their conversation. “You’re awesome, you’re dead-on, and we’re going to learn a lot from you,” he enthused.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 349, May 25, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Weinstein’s Lawyer Tried to Intimidate Witnesses, Prosecutors Say
description: Arthur Aidala, one of Harvey Weinstein’s lawyers, has questioned a witness’s credibility as prosecutors seek to retry Mr. Weinstein on sex crimes charges.
content: The Manhattan district attorney’s office has asked the judge overseeing Harvey Weinstein’s retrial on sex crimes charges to urge the lead defense lawyer to stop making public statements that prosecutors said were intended to intimidate and to attack the “credibility and character” of witnesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Farrell
title: Facing Possible Cash Crunch, Giant Real Estate Fund Limits Withdrawals
description: Starwood Real Estate Income Trust is restricting what investors can redeem rather than sell its properties to raise cash.
content: A giant real estate fund managed by the company of the billionaire investor Barry Sternlicht is limiting the amount of money that investors can redeem, in an attempt to fend off a potential cash crunch as high interest rates pummel the market for commercial properties like office buildings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: At These Restaurants, Feeding the Staff Comes First
description: The “family meal” tradition of serving workers before customers is getting new life as a perk, a motivator and a teaching tool.
content: When Eric Ripert was a young cook at La Tour D’Argent, possibly the oldest restaurant in Paris and certainly one of the stuffiest, all the cooks sat down before service to a proper French meal: appetizer, entree, dessert and cheese.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent Staples
title: Fixing the Calamity in U.S. Math Knowledge Starts With Algebra
description: Giving up means that math scores will continue to plummet and racial gaps will grow.
content: The federal government made a disastrous choice a decade ago when it abandoned an accountability system (known as No Child Left Behind) that required schools to focus intently on helping the lowest-performing students catch up with their peers. Since then, the already alarming achievement gaps that separate poor and wealthy children have only widened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes and Dani Blum
title: Bird Flu Virus Found in Beef Tissue
description: Muscle from a sick dairy cow tested positive for the virus. The meat did not enter the commercial food supply, which officials said remained safe.
content: Beef tissue from a sick dairy cow has tested positive for the bird flu virus, federal officials said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: For the Best Nonalcoholic Wines, Look to Germany
description: The country has a long history — more than a century — of making nonalcoholic wines. It’s no wonder they’re good.
content: As interest in nonalcoholic wines grows, some of the best in the genre are being made in Germany, which started producing nonalcoholic wines more than 100 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: How to Make the Most of Summer
description: You don’t need a vacation to embrace a sunnier state of mind.
content: Summer may be a few weeks away, but Memorial Day weekend is often when people start asking if you have vacation plans. And for many reasons, including work demands or a tight budget, the answer might be “nope.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: The Emails at the Heart of the Government’s Ticketmaster Case
description: Live Nation Entertainment, which owns Ticketmaster, is accused of violating antitrust laws. The Justice Department drew on the concert behemoth’s internal communications in its lawsuit.
content: In its lawsuit accusing Live Nation Entertainment, the concert behemoth that owns Ticketmaster, of being an illegal monopoly, the Justice Department drew on a raft of internal communications that offered a rare behind-the-scenes look at the industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly
title: Are These Drones Too Chinese to Pass U.S. Muster in an Anti-China Moment?
description: U.S.-based Anzu Robotics is selling drones using technology from DJI, a Chinese firm that is the target of efforts by lawmakers to limit Chinese technology in America.
content: A one-man startup believes it has an answer to U.S. government concerns over the Chinese-made drones that dominate commercial sales in the American market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Hot dogs, hot slaw and plenty of ranch
description: The point, on a long weekend that heralds the start of a new season, is to cook with the intention of delivering pleasure as much as sustenance.
content: Good morning. There’s always something celebratory about Memorial Day weekend, even though it’s meant to be a somber affair, honoring those who have given their lives in service to the nation. We raise our flags high, but also our grilling tools, our string lights over the yard (or around the railings of the fire escape), our hopes for a long, pleasant summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Top U.N. Court Decision Adds to Israel’s Growing Isolation
description: An order to stop the Rafah offensive was the latest action against Israel, all of which create “a tremendous sense of pressure,” a former consul general said.
content: In 2011, a former Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, warned that Israel faced a “diplomatic-political tsunami” of censure if its conflict with the Palestinians went unresolved, as peace talks faltered and revolution spread across the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: The N.C.A.A.’s Landmark Athlete-Pay Settlement, Explained
description: The $2.8 billion agreement announced on Thursday would, if approved by a judge, allow college athletes to share team revenue for the first time. Here is what we know.
content: When the N.C.A.A. and the major athletic conferences agreed on Thursday night to a $2.8 billion settlement of a class-action antitrust lawsuit by college athletes, it was a pivotal moment in the long history of college sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Caleb Carr, Author of Dark Histories, Dies at 68
description: His own dark history prompted him to write about and investigate the roots of violence, notably in his best-selling novel “The Alienist.”
content: Caleb Carr, a military historian and author whose experience of childhood abuse drove him to explore the roots of violence — most famously in his 1994 best seller, “The Alienist,” a period thriller about the hunt for a serial killer in 19th-century Manhattan — died on Thursday at his home in Cherry Plains, N.Y. He was 68.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Sean Kingston Arrested on Fraud and Theft Charges After Raid at His Home
description: Mr. Kingston, a singer and rapper, best known for his 2007 hit single “Beautiful Girls,” was taken into custody on Thursday. His mother was also arrested.
content: The singer and rapper Sean Kingston was arrested in California on Thursday, hours after a SWAT team raided his home in Broward County, Fla., and took his mother into custody, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Friends?
description: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
content: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this image, or write about a memory from your own life that this illustration makes you think of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘The Beach Boys’ Review: How to Make Good Vibrations
description: This Disney documentary looks at the family ties and sweet harmonies that turned a California band into a popular treasure.
content: The wholesome ocean-breeze look of the Beach Boys could make the group a punchline if it weren’t for their sweet sunshine sound. The origins of their intricate harmonies undergird “The Beach Boys,” a Disney documentary directed by Frank Marshall and Thom Zimny that notes obstacles in the band’s career but mostly tries to keep the good vibrations going.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur and Adam Satariano
title: Russia, in New Push, Increasingly Disrupts Ukraine’s Starlink Service
description: Russia has deployed advanced tech to interfere with Elon Musk’s satellite internet service, Ukrainian officials said, leading to more outages on the northern front battle line.
content: Just before Russian troops pushed across the Ukrainian northern border this month, members of Ukraine’s 92nd Assault Brigade lost a vital resource. Starlink satellite internet service, which soldiers use to communicate, collect intelligence and conduct drone attacks, had slowed to a crawl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Walker Mimms
title: 48 Attempts to Understand the Creative Spirit
description: In “The Work of Art,” famed creators from the worlds of film, fashion, theater and more explore the hidden alchemy of their craft.
content: Why anything exists at all is the first question of philosophy, Heidegger once said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Italian Teenager to Become the First Millennial Saint
description: Pope Francis attributed a second miracle to Carlo Acutis, one of the last steps toward canonization.
content: Pope Francis cleared the way for an Italian teenager to become the first millennial saint by attributing a second miracle to him, the Vatican announced Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquín
title: After Outcry, Chuck E. Cheese Says It Will Keep More Animatronic Bands
description: Plans to phase out most of Chuck E. Cheese’s animatronic bands prompted fans to plead for their survival. The bands will now play on at three additional locations.
content: After Chuck E. Cheese’s plans to retire most of its animatronic bands sparked an outcry from wistful fans, the pizzeria-arcade chain said it would keep a few more of the bands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee, Bilal Shbair and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: As Rafah Offensive Grinds On, Hunger in Gaza Spirals
description: Aid officials and health experts expect famine this month unless Israel lifts barriers to aid, the fighting stops and vital services are restored.
content: For weeks, the Gaza Strip’s southernmost city, Rafah, was one of the few places where desperate Gazans could find some aid and food. Bakeries sold bread; fuel powered generators; markets were open, if expensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: With a Body Double, an Artist Reflects on Life as a Trans-Deaf Influencer
description: Chella Man, a 25-year-old model and actor, has turned to performance and sculpture to understand their identity.
content: A spotlight dimmed as the artist Chella Man signaled to a section of the audience where their parents were seated in all-white costumes. In a haunting approach, the parents tiptoed toward an eerily lifelike replica of their child’s body and carefully transferred the silicone doppelgänger to an operating table. There, as part of the performance piece “Autonomy,” Man performed two surgeries that had helped define their experience as a deaf and trans teenager.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeğinsu
title: Here It Comes: Another Hot Summer in Europe
description: Extreme heat and other weather challenges are in the forecast this summer, and travel advisers, tourists and local officials are getting prepared.
content: Europe, the world’s fastest-warming continent, is headed for another scorching summer, meteorologists warn. And travelers, once again, are heading to the hot spots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nia Decaille
title: Are You Wearing Sunscreen the Right Way?
description: And other essential questions about protecting your skin from the sun, answered by experts.
content: You probably know that you need to wear sunscreen. And you probably know the effects of not doing so: Too much exposure to UV rays can hasten signs of aging, worsen skin conditions and even lead to skin cancer — not to mention leave you with a painful burn. But when and how much sunscreen should you be applying? Does it matter what kind? And what do you do if, despite your best efforts, you do get a burn? Here, skin-care and cosmetic experts share their advice for protecting your body, from head to toe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Blackstone’s Chief, a G.O.P. Megadonor, Says He Will Again Back Trump
description: Stephen A. Schwarzman, the billionaire co-founder and chief executive of the investment group, had previously called for a “new generation of leaders.”
content: Stephen A. Schwarzman, the billionaire chairman and chief executive of the Blackstone Group, said he would back former President Donald J. Trump in the 2024 election, a reversal from his call for a “new generation of leaders” after the midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: The Cannes Love Affair With American Cinema Takes Unexpected Turns
description: Whether it’s Demi Moore’s performance in “The Substance” or Sean Baker’s tale of a Brooklyn sex worker, this year’s jury will have a lot to ponder.
content: One truism of the Cannes Film Festival is that no matter how alarming the news about the American movie world, Hollywood — however you understand that word — retains a powerful grip on this event. Cannes is a thoroughly French affair, but its love for le cinéma américain is evident everywhere from the faded images of Hollywood stars that are scattered about to the honorary awards that the event bestows. On Saturday, it will present an honorary Palme d’Or to George Lucas, the 11th American to get an award that it’s given out just 22 times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John White, Lynn Levy, Alyssa Moxley, Dan Powell and Ben Sisario
title: Meet the Jimi Hendrix of the Sahara
description: Our music reporter on Mdou Moctar and other African guitar heroes
content: Our music reporter Ben Sisario takes us on a journey through West Africa’s guitar music scene past and present, highlighting a handful of songs from the genre’s most innovative and influential bands. This playlist showcases an eclectic mix of styles — from desert blues and psychedelic rock to Afro-Cuban music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: A Lender to Consumer Start-Ups Falters, Rattling Its Clients
description: Ampla, which lent money to smaller businesses that sold clothing, home furnishings and other items directly to consumers, is struggling financially and seeking a buyer.
content: A popular lender backed by venture capital firms is struggling financially, sending shock waves through the small clothing and home furnishing companies that count on its financing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: ‘Old’ Amsterdam Looks Back at New Amsterdam Through Indigenous Eyes
description: The violent history of the Dutch colony that is now New York is not well known in the Netherlands. The curators of a new exhibition want to change that.
content: In the language of the Lenape Indigenous people, the word for European explorers who crossed the Atlantic in the 17th century to settle on their lands was “shuwankook,” or “salty people.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Rachel Cohn, Whitney Jones, Jen Poyant, Alyssa Moxley, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Rowan Niemisto
title: ScarJo vs. ChatGPT, Neuralink’s First Patient Opens Up, and Microsoft’s A.I. PCs
description: “Did you ever think we would have a literal Avenger fighting back against the relentless march of A.I.? Because that’s sort of what this story is about.”
content: This week, more drama at OpenAI: The company wanted Scarlett Johansson to be a voice of GPT-4o, she said no … but something got lost in translation. Then we talk with Noland Arbaugh, the first person to get Elon Musk’s Neuralink device implanted in his brain, about how his brain-computer interface has changed his life. And finally, the Times’s Karen Weise reports back from Microsoft’s developer conference, where the big buzz was that the company’s new line of A.I. PCs will record every single thing you do on the device.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: University Leaders Face a Long, Complex Summer
description: Many officials may be confronting federal investigations, disputes over student discipline — and the prospect that the protests start all over again in the fall.
content: Around now, university officials might usually take a deep breath. Campuses are emptying out for the end of the academic year. Gone, for the most part, are the tent cities that student activists erected as a symbol of opposition to Israel’s war in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s villains include naughty gay ghosts, savage seniors and a dangerously unhinged bro.
content: Have you ever said to someone: “I would kill to spend more time with you”? The characters in Daniel Montgomery’s gay horror comedy say it a lot, with macabre but unexpectedly tender and very funny consequences for the living and the dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Kennedy and Trump Go to Battle Over Libertarians
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. made his case to the Libertarian Party convention on Friday, jumping into a fight over right-leaning, independent-minded voters.
content: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the independent candidate for president, pitched his bid to the Libertarian Party on Friday, telling a potentially critical group of voters that he stands with them on “valuing personal liberty” and vowing to protect their rights to speak, to assemble and to “keep and bear arms.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,071, May 25, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Want to Better Understand America? Consider All-You-Can-Eat Shrimp.
description: The downfall of Red Lobster suggests consumers are parched for value.
content: The great economist George Stigler wrote a paper called “The Cost of Subsistence” that calculated the minimum cost of food that would satisfy the nutritional requirements of “an active economist” who “lives in a large city.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen and Remy Tumin
title: Morgan Spurlock, Documentarian Known for ‘Super Size Me,’ Dies at 53
description: His 2004 film followed Mr. Spurlock as he ate nothing but McDonald’s for a month. It was nominated for an Oscar, but it later came in for criticism.
content: Morgan Spurlock, a documentary filmmaker who gained fame with his Oscar-nominated 2004 film “Super Size Me,” which followed him as he ate nothing but McDonald’s for 30 days — but later stepped back from the public eye after admitting to sexual misconduct — died on Thursday in New York City. He was 53.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa
title: These Teens Adopted an Orphaned Oil Well. Their Goal: Shut It Down.
description: Students, nonprofit groups and others are fund-raising to cap highly polluting oil and gas wells abandoned by industry.
content: As a child in Bolivia, Mateo De La Rocha told his family he wanted to work as a garbage man when he grew up. In La Paz, his home city at the time, trash piles were everywhere. In Mr. De La Rocha’s eyes, the local sanitation worker was the only person cleaning up pollution. “I didn’t really see anyone doing anything about it, apart from the garbage man,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: How FaceTime Calls With Mom Became a TV Hit
description: What started as a way for the filmmaker Josh Seftel and his mother, Pat, to stay in touch has become a popular feature on “CBS Sunday Morning.”
content: At 87, Pat Seftel has a thought to share about almost everything.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brittani Samuel
title: Review: In ‘The Fires,’ a Triptych of Stories About Gay Men and Love
description: Raja Feather Kelly makes his playwriting debut with a spellbinding story of three generations of Black men at Soho Rep.
content: The choreographer Raja Feather Kelly’s dance-theater works have made him a mainstay on the downtown arts scene. With his latest piece, “The Fires,” Kelly is making his debut as a playwright. Rarely does a show live up so honestly to its title — wrecking and illuminating in equal measure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Kabosu, Shiba Inu Who Helped Define the Doge Meme, Dies at 18
description: The dog, whose face helped spread the popular doge meme and later became the logo of the Dogecoin cryptocurrency, died on Friday.
content: Kabosu, a Shiba Inu whose “much wow” face helped launch one of the defining memes of the last decade and inspired the cryptocurrency Dogecoin, died on Friday. She was 18 years old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: The Rolling Stones Really Might Never Stop
description: During a 19-song set at MetLife Stadium that spanned 60 years, the band tapped into what seems like a bottomless well of rock ’n’ roll energy.
content: “This song’s for Manhattan!” Mick Jagger told the crowd on Thursday night at MetLife Stadium, before launching into a punchy rendition of “Shattered,” that agitated ode to late-70s New York City that closes out the band’s 1978 album “Some Girls.” In the ensuing 46 years, the city has changed in some superficial ways but somehow remained essentially the same — much, as they showed throughout an impressively energetic two-hour set, like the Rolling Stones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Can I Use A.I. to Grade My Students’ Papers?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on artificial intelligence platforms, and whether it’s hypocritical for teachers to use these tools while forbidding students from doing the same.
content: I am a junior-high-school English teacher. In the past school year, there has been a significant increase in students’ cheating on writing assignments by using artificial intelligence. Our department feels that 13-year-old students will only become better writers if they practice and learn from the successes and challenges that come with that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ella Quittner
title: Is This the End of Instagram Cookware?
description: Once-hot direct-to-consumer pots and pans are up for grabs on secondhand marketplaces at steep discounts — or ending in the garbage.
content: Just a few months after the pandemic sent Americans indoors, Mia Graber received a lidded nonstick skillet the color of spruce pine needles, complete with a steamer basket and a wooden spatula on the handle, as a gift from her husband.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Biden’s Chance to Do the Right Thing in Gaza
description: The U.S. should side with the International Court of Justice in the Gaza war.
content: In a speech in Warsaw two years ago, President Biden declared that “the great battle for freedom” is one “between a rules-based order and one governed by brute force.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Harrison Butker’s Very American Traditionalism
description: How Latin Mass Catholics embody the spirit of Vatican II.
content: Across almost two weeks of controversy over the commencement speech that Kansas City Chiefs kicker Harrison Butker gave at Benedictine College in Atchison, Kan., one of the most useful pieces of commentary came from Kevin Tierney, writing in Catholic World Report. Tierney neither defended nor attacked Butker’s sweeping condemnation of modern secular culture and lukewarm forms of Catholic faith. Instead he identified the kicker’s worldview as part of a distinctive tendency that Tierney calls “DIY traditionalism” — a form of Catholic piety that offers a “radical emphasis on personal accountability, is inherently populist, and has little direct connection to Church authorities.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellina Moore
title: ‘Furiosa: A Mad Max Saga’: What Do Critics Say? What Do You Say?
description: The reviews all agree that the follow-up to “Fury Road” feels sadder and heavier. But is that a good thing? That’s where the disagreements start.
content: Following up what is considered one of the greatest action movies of the last decade is no easy feat. But that was the task facing George Miller as he set out to make a prequel to his Oscar-winning 2015 blockbuster, “Mad Max: Fury Road.” The result, “Furiosa: A Mad Max Saga,” tells the origin story of the Imperator Furiosa, the breakout character who first appeared in “Fury Road” — played by Charlize Theron then and Anya Taylor-Joy now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: Judge Judy’s Manhattan Duplex Is Listed for $9.5 Million
description: Judith Sheindlin and her husband’s Manhattan penthouse at 14 Sutton Place South is for sale for the first time in a decade.
content: Judith Sheindlin, better known as TV’s Judge Judy, is putting her Manhattan home, a duplex penthouse with a wraparound terrace and scenic East River views, on the market for the first time in more than a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Some Eye Shadows
description: Carolyn Davies Lynch opens our solving weekend.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Brooke Shields Elected President of Stage Actors’ Union
description: She takes office immediately. The previous leader of Actors’ Equity, Kate Shindle, had been president since 2015, and did not run again.
content: Brooke Shields, the model-turned-actor who has starred in films, on television and onstage, has been elected as the next president of Actors’ Equity Association, the labor union representing stage actors and stage managers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: John Koerner, Bluesman Who Inspired a Young Bob Dylan, Dies at 85
description: A spindly guitarist nicknamed Spider, Mr. Koerner was Mr. Dylan’s first friend in the scruffy world of Minneapolis bohemia where he learned about folk music.
content: Spider John Koerner, a blues and folk singer whose work drew praise from the Doors and the Beatles (if not the general public) and who, in 1960, taught his friend Bobby Zimmerman about traditional American music, then watched as the young man metamorphosed into Bob Dylan, died on Saturday at his home in Minneapolis. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Uvalde Families Accuse Instagram, ‘Call of Duty’ and Rifle Maker of ‘Grooming’ Gunman
description: The unusual lawsuits filed on Friday are among the most far-reaching to be filed in response to the escalating number of mass shootings in the United States.
content: The families of schoolchildren who were shot at Robb Elementary School in 2022 filed two lawsuits on Friday accusing Instagram, the publisher of the popular “Call of Duty” video game and a manufacturer of semiautomatic rifles of helping to train and equip the teenage gunman who committed the massacre.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Ukraine Starts Freeing Some Prisoners to Join Its Military
description: Nearly 350 inmates have been freed under a new law that allows them to serve in exchange for the possibility of parole, the country’s justice minister said.
content: Ukraine has begun releasing prisoners to serve in its army, part of a wider effort to rebuild a military that has been depleted by more than two years of war and is strained by relentless Russian assaults.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: An Extraordinary Documentary About the Most Precious of Lives
description: Margreth Olin’s “Songs of Earth” works almost like a poem as she records her parents and the Norwegian landscape.
content: It’s rare to see a film that feels not just poetic in nature, but like actual poetry. The rhythm and cadence, the imagery and metaphor, even the sense of movement and time that often accompany a great poem don’t translate easily to the screen. Filmmakers need a light touch and trust in the viewer to lean in and let their work wash over them, rather than trying to decode everything.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: ‘Zarqa’ Is a Madcap Canadian Comedy
description: This new YouTube sitcom from the creator of “Little Mosque on the Prairie” follows a divorced Muslim mother trying to pull one over on her ex.
content: The Canadian sitcom “Little Mosque on the Prairie” premiered in 2007 and centered on a small Muslim community in a fictional Saskatchewan town. It ran for 91 episodes over six seasons, eventually showing around the world (it is streaming on Freevee, the Roku Channel and Tubi). Now its creator, Zarqa Nawaz, has a new short-form comedy with a narrower focus but a similar cartoony vibe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cathcart Robbins
title: Marriage Made an Actor Out of Me
description: I deserved an Oscar for my performances as best supporting wife and mother. After my divorce, I could no longer pretend to be someone I’m not.
content: My divorce, though comparatively gentle and humane, still left me shattered, bone-tired and distrustful. Throughout our 12-year marriage, I felt like I had been playing the role of a high-society Hollywood wife and mother, and I no longer knew who I really was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Fred Roos, Casting Director and Coppola Collaborator, Dies at 89
description: Widely considered to have the best eye for talent in Hollywood, he shared the best-picture Oscar with Francis Ford Coppola for “The Godfather Part II.”
content: Fred Roos, a casting director and producer who championed the early careers of A-list actors like Al Pacino, Jack Nicholson and Carrie Fisher, and whose long collaboration with Francis Ford Coppola and his family, stretching from “The Godfather” (1972) to this year’s “Megalopolis,” earned him an Oscar and an Emmy, died on Saturday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Trump Warms Up to Bringing Haley ‘On Our Team in Some Form’
description: The former president praised Nikki Haley, once his bitter rival for the Republican nomination, a day after she said that she would vote for him.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump on Thursday opened the door to bringing Nikki Haley into his circle, another step in what looked to be a thawing of hostilities between the two former rivals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: The Business Ties That Bind the U.S. and China Are Strong but Fraying
description: The prospects for future commerce, and peace, are intertwined, our columnist writes.
content: If you follow the news, you know that tensions between the United States and China are high and that the commercial relationship between the two biggest trading nations on the planet has been fraying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Ozempic Cuts Risk of Chronic Kidney Disease Complications, Study Finds
description: A major clinical trial showed such promising results that the drug’s maker halted it early.
content: Semaglutide, the compound in the blockbuster drugs Ozempic and Wegovy, dramatically reduced the risk of kidney complications, heart issues and death in people with Type 2 diabetes and chronic kidney disease in a major clinical trial, the results of which were published on Friday. The findings could transform how doctors treat some of the sickest patients with chronic kidney disease, which affects more than one in seven adults in the United States but has no cure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Countries Fail to Agree on Treaty to Prepare the World for the Next Pandemic
description: Negotiators plan to ask for more time. Among the sticking points are equitable access to vaccines and financing to set up surveillance systems.
content: Countries around the globe have failed to reach consensus on the terms of a treaty that would unify the world in a strategy against the inevitable next pandemic, trumping the nationalist ethos that emerged during Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: Trump’s V.P. Pageant Has an Unexpectedly Strong Contender: Tom Cotton
description: Donald Trump’s interest in the Arkansas senator reflects a desire to choose a running mate with experience and the ability to run a disciplined campaign.
content: Senator Tom Cotton of Arkansas has unexpectedly emerged as a top contender to become Donald J. Trump’s running mate, a signal that the former president is heavily weighing experience and the ability to run a disciplined campaign over other factors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: ‘The Daily Show’ Skewers Samuel Alito Over Another Provocative Flag
description: “Did this guy get a two-for-one deal at the MAGA flag store?” Michael Kosta said of the Supreme Court justice on Thursday’s “The Daily Show.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: Israeli Forces Cut Off Access to Kamal Adwan Hospital in Northern Gaza
description: Israeli bombardments and raids have put many of Gaza’s hospitals out of operation and only a few remain even partially functional.
content: Israeli forces massed at the entrance to a major hospital in the northern Gaza Strip on Friday, trapping more than a dozen medical personnel inside and all but putting one of the last functioning hospitals out of operation, according to a doctor and Palestinian news media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles and David C. Adams
title: Three Missionaries in Haiti Killed in Gang Attack
description: The latest assault by Haitian gangs left three people, including two American missionaries and a local pastor, dead in Port-au-Prince.
content: An Oklahoma-based missionary group working in Haiti’s capital was attacked by gangs on Thursday night, leaving two Americans and the group’s director dead, the organization, Missions in Haiti, announced on Facebook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: A Jaw-Dropping Question is Answered a Decade Later
description: Nora O’Neill and Gabriel Grand began dating in 2014. Ms. O’Neill’s twin had an inkling then that the relationship was going to get serious.
content: Nora Patrice O’Neill and Gabriel Grand had only been dating a couple of months when her twin brother, Patrick, posed a jaw-dropping question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: U.N. Court Orders Israel to Halt Rafah Offensive
description: The International Court of Justice ruling deepens Israel’s international isolation, but the court has no enforcement powers.
content: The International Court of Justice on Friday ruled that Israel must immediately halt its military offensive in the southern Gaza city of Rafah, dealing another blow to the country as it faces increasing international isolation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: 6 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
content: Gary (played by Glen Powell) is a reserved philosophy professor who finds himself posing as a hit man for a sting operation in this Richard Linklater comedy. While in disguise, he falls for one of his clients (Adria Arjona).

content: Just after 7 a.m. on Saturday, Nov. 18, as the sun was rising in the Gulf of Mexico, Noel Rangel, a 26-year-old native of Brownsville, Texas, was brought unwillingly into wakefulness by an uninvited sensation: The richest man in the world was shaking him. Or rather, his entire apartment. His bed was rumbling, his windows rattling. “I could hear the glass,” he said. He was confused. He woke as if Elon Musk himself had grabbed him by the shoulders.
